content.body: I highly, highly doubt `.call` is actually used that much in real code. It might be counting library code a bunch?
content.formatted_body: I highly, highly doubt .call is actually used that much in real code. It might be counting library code a bunch?

content.body:
> <@tabatkins:matrix.org> I highly, highly doubt `.call` is actually used that much in real code. It might be counting library code a bunch?

I actually checked the first thousand lines of its output and they all generally seem legitimate to me.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @tabatkins:matrix.org
I highly, highly doubt .call is actually used that much in real code. It might be counting library code a bunch?
I actually checked the first thousand lines of its output and they all generally seem legitimate to me.

content.body: I can dump them in a Gist.
Mostly stuff like `_super.call(this, destination)` or `tryCatch(onCancelCallback).call(this._boundValue())`.
Oh, you’re asking if it’s double-counting dependencies.
I don’t…think it should…
I’ll check with `uniq`.

Sorting the output then running `uniq -d` doesn’t return any duplicate lines. It doesn’t seem to be double-counting dependencies. 
At most, a library might manually include the code of another library in its own source code, but that problem is probably pretty small. And it applies to all the other functions’ counts, too.
content.formatted_body:
Sorting the output then running uniq -d doesn’t return any duplicate lines. It doesn’t seem to be double-counting dependencies.
At most, a library might manually include the code of another library in its own source code, but that problem is probably pretty small. And it applies to all the other functions’ counts, too.

content.body: …I’d upload the sorted dump, but I just realized not everyone might want to download a 75.9-MB file, and I don’t know how Matrix’s file sharing works, haha.

(Fun fact: The most-downloaded NPM library that uses `.call`, as of 2019-09, was debug, and it uses `.call` twice: in `createDebug.formatArgs.call(self, args)` and in `match = formatter.call(self, val);`.)
content.formatted_body: (Fun fact: The most-downloaded NPM library that uses .call, as of 2019-09, was debug, and it uses .call twice: in createDebug.formatArgs.call(self, args) and in match = formatter.call(self, val);.)

content.body: (Next up is kind-of, which uses `.call` once, followed by readable-stream…which uses `.call` nineteen times.)
content.formatted_body: (Next up is kind-of, which uses .call once, followed by readable-stream…which uses .call nineteen times.)

content.body: Ashley Claymore: I think it would be incorrect to call a Symbol's [[Description]] an internal slot. It's just something else ("an associated value") that happens to use the same metasyntax.
content.formatted_body: Ashley Claymore: I think it would be incorrect to call a Symbol's [[Description]] an internal slot. It's just something else ("an associated value") that happens to use the same metasyntax.

content.body: thanks :D

When Symbols were first introduced in the early drafts of ES 6, they were a kind of exotic object, so at that time, [[Description]] *would* have been an internal slot, except that by the time [[Description]] showed up, Symbols had already changed to be a new kind of primitive.
content.formatted_body: When Symbols were first introduced in the early drafts of ES 6, they were a kind of exotic object, so at that time, [[Description]] would have been an internal slot, except that by the time [[Description]] showed up, Symbols had already changed to be a new kind of primitive.

content.body: ah - that's an interesting bit of history

jmdyck: symbol descriptions are 100% an internal slot, and the getter works across realms
